habitat_description:
Disjunct populations of the lined snake occur across Illinois, Iowa, extreme southwestern Minnesota, extreme southeastern South Dakota, eastern Colorado, Missouri, Kansas, Oklahoma, Texas, and New Mexico (Conant and Collins 1991; Degenhardt et al. 1996; Ernst and Ernst 2003; Hammerson 1999; Johnson 2000; Oldfield and Moriarty 1994; Phillips et al. 1999; Stebbins 2003; Werler and Dixon 2000).

Riparian zones and moist areas are its habitat of preference, but this species is also commonly found in grassland, herbaceous, savanna, and suburban terrestrial habitats. This species is known to burrow using soil, or in soil, debris, decaying logs, and leaf litter. Individuals are often observed in prairie hillsides, woodland edges, canyon bottoms, residential yards, abandoned trash dumps, and vacant city lots. Moist areas where this snake occurs include areas not strictly near a body of water or wetland (Collins 1993; Degenhardt et al. 1996; Ernst and Ernst 2003; Hammerson 1999; Johnson 2000; Phillips et al. 1999; Werler and Dixon 2000).

Uses rocks, trash, logs, and leaf litter as cover.
